results.title: Gough Whitlam - Dismissal
results.brief_description: Australia confronted its most controversial and arguably its most far-reaching constitutional crisis when the Governor-General exercised contentious reserve powers to dismiss the Gough Whitlam-led Labor Government on November 11, 1975.

constellations_primary.name: Dismissing the truth
constellations_primary.description: The dismissal of Gough Whitlam by Governor-General Sir John Kerr is one of the most controversial moments in Australian politics. Whitlam’s rebuttal imploring the electorate to ‘maintain the rage’ was immortalised on TV and took on the gravitas of Shakespearean tragedy.

results.description: Australia confronted its most controversial and arguably its most far-reaching constitutional crisis when the Governor-General of the day, Sir John Kerr, exercised contentious reserve powers to dismiss the Gough Whitlam-led Labor Government on November 11, 1975. Whitlam’s defiance was immortalised in his televised ‘nothing will save the Governor-General’ rebuttal; an impassioned speech in which he implored the electorate to ‘maintain the rage’ and which took on the gravitas of Shakespearean tragedy in the face of Labor’s landslide election defeat only a month later, in December 1975.
description_for_label: Australia confronted its most controversial and arguably its most far-reaching constitutional crisis when the Governor-General of the day, Sir John Kerr, exercised contentious reserve powers to dismiss the Gough Whitlam-led Labor Government on November 11, 1975. Whitlam’s defiance was immortalised in his televised ‘nothing will save the Governor-General’ rebuttal; an impassioned speech in which he implored the electorate to ‘maintain the rage’ and which took on the gravitas of Shakespearean tragedy in the face of Labor’s landslide election defeat only a month later, in December 1975.

results.title: Gotterdammerung: fall of the Third Reich
results.creator_credit: Jack Kaufman, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and Wolper Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Rise and fall of the Third Reich”.
Third and final part of a series based on the book by William L. Shirer ‘The Rise and Fall of the Third Reich’. This episode deals with the period 1941-1945, showing the first gradual and then accelerated reverses of the German army.

results.title: Gotterdammerung
results.creator_credit: Brian Large, Deutsche Grammophon and Metropolitan Opera (New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description: This is the final catastrophic opera in Wagner’s ‘The Ring of the Nibelung’. The redemption of the world through love is achieved at the end of Gotterdammerung, with the annihilation of both men and gods. Conducted by James Levine and featuring Siegfried Jerusalem. Wagner’s “Ring Cycle” consists of four parts in the following order: Das Rheingold; Die Walkuere; Siegfreid and Goetterdaemmerung.

results.title: Gothic art
results.brief_description: Presents aspects of emerging art forms in Northern Europe during the period dating from the late 12th century to the 15th century. Emphasises the origins of Gothic art as manifested in St Denis Abbey Church and Chartres Cathedral. Pictorial reproductions from Life Magazine 1949. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Got at (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Patricia Edgar and Centre for Study of Educational Communication and Media
results.brief_description: Presents the attitudes of a group of women trainee teachers towards sex-role socialisation. Seeks to stimulate discussion about the role teachers and school organizations play in fostering, reinforcing or changing sex-role stereotyping in Australian society.

results.title: Gospel truth
results.creator_credit: Mischa Scorer, Antelope Films and Channel 4
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Testament: The Bible and history”.
This episode explores the writing of the New Testament looking at the identity of Jesus Christ and his followers, his persecutors and his biographers, the Gospel writers. Also discussed is the gradual spread of Christianity throughout the Roman Empire which escalated once the Gospels became written accounts rather than spread by word of mouth.

results.title: Gorilla girls
results.creator_credit: Fiona Cochrane, Louise Hubbard, f-reel and Film Victoria
results.brief_description: A women’s basketball team, the underdog “Lady Gorilla’s”, play a win-or-die game and in doing so attack some of their personal demons. They talk and play tough because this is how life has treated them and and now with their sponsors threatening to pull the plug, the game takes on a bigger significance. They face “The Sharks” who are at the top of the ladder in what will be the game of their life.

results.title: Gorilla
results.creator_credit: Barbara Jampel, National Geographic Society and WQED
results.brief_description: A film about the gorilla, a shy, gentle, intelligent creature threatened with extinction. Learn about gorilla behaviour and what is being done to save the gorilla.

results.title: Gorilla
results.creator_credit: Brian Leith, BBC and Discovery Channel
results.brief_description: Narrated by David Attenborough, this documentary follows three newly discovered colonies of Lowland Gorillas in the northern Congo, exploring the true nature of the great Ape. This film is a masterpiece of expertise and innovation, award-winning cameraman Gavin Thurston and his crew use revolutionary techniques, backed by some of the latest scientific research to reveal aspects of the gorilla’s lives that have never been seen before in their natural environment.

results.title: Gorgeous (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Kaz Cooke, Sharon Connolly and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Follows the perils of cartoon character Hermoine the Modern Girl as she tackles plastic surgery, beauty therapy and bulimia, in a feral fit of inadequacy. ‘Gorgeous’ asks why men and women feel insecure and what thoughts tempt them towards eating disorders and other strange eating rituals. Hermoine proves that modern girls can stop feeling inadequate and regain their self-esteem.
